Yes, you should switch, to double your chances of success. As this thread has been dead for a month, I'm going to post up the reasoning. I've been tempted to do this for a while...
 
 Consider the possible outcomes of the first choice. Because there is only one prize but three doors, you must have a 1 in 3 chance of picking the right door and a corresponding 2 in 3 chance of picking the incorrect door.
 
 However, the host then removes an 'empty' door. This means that there are only two doors left, one of which has a prize and one of which doesn't. As such, if you switch doors then you are guaranteed to go from prize to not-prize, or vice versa, from not-prize to prize. This means that, should you switch, the 1/3 chance of picking the prize door from the first choice becomes a 1/3 chance that you will switch to an empty door. Equally, the 2/3 chance that you miss the prize door on your first choice becomes a 2/3 chance that you will switch from that empty door to the prize one.
 
 Thus if you switch you have a 2/3 chance of getting the correct door, compared to the 1/3 chance of failure. However, if you decide to stick with the same door then all you have is the 1/3 chance of success from your first choice - halving your chances.
 
 A more diagrammatical approach is shown below. In it, 'P' indicates a door with a prize, 'E' indicates an empty door, and the bolded letter indicates your currently selected door.
 
 SWITCH
 
 PEE ------< one E removed -----< PE
 EPE ------< one E removed -----< EP
 EEP ------< one E removed -----< EP
 
 2/3 chance of winning.
 
 STICK
 
 PEE ------< one E removed -----< PE
 EPE ------< one E removed -----< EP
 EEP ------< one E removed -----< EP
 
 1/3 chance of winning.

 I've got a problem in this because at one stage we're counting "three doors", but counting only "two doors" as options in the "switch".
 We count "three doors" as options as to what we could have the prize behind and switch to, but that isn't the scenario we actually have.
 It presents a false count.
 
 Suppose we have chosen Door #1, and the host eliminates Door #3.
 We can't count "door #3" options in our diagram because that choice is no longer valid. It has been proven that the prize is not behind door #3. Our "new" options are suddenly including a door which has been eliminated from the game?
 
 Therefore, I present that we have the following:
 
 1 2 3 - If prize is behind door 1 and you pick door 1 then staying would win you the prize
 1 2 3 - If prize is behind door 1 and you pick door 2 then switching would win you the prize
 
 1 2 3 - If prize is behind door 2 and you pick door 1 then switching would win you the prize
 1 2 3 - If prize is behind door 2 and you pick door 2 then staying would win you the prize
 
 You have a 50-50 chance.
 
 Look at it another way.
 Suppose you were originally given TWO choices, and then you pick a door.
 The host comes along and says "Oh. By the way, we were originally going to give you THREE door options, and here is the third door. The prize is not behind door #3."
 Does that mean you should switch your choice now? 
 
 Or how about we take another turn at this?
 If I suddenly revealed the other door as not having the prize (so you now have only one door there), and presented the option of changing your choice, would you now be counting the second door as being a possible source for the prize?
 
 The prize was never behind the now excluded door. That is new knowledge that you gain, which does change your chances but the re-calculated chances should not count now excluded door.

I've got a problem in this because at one stage we're counting "three doors", but counting only "two doors" as options in the "switch".
 We count "three doors" as options as to what we could have the prize behind and switch to, but that isn't the scenario we actually have.
 It presents a false count.

 The thing is that here you aren't making two completely separate decisions. Instead, you are making one stretched out decision with additional information half-way through the decision-making process - so the initial number of doors is important.
 
 Look at it a different way - assume that you have decided, pre-game, that you are going to pick an arbitrary door and then switch. If you initially get the prize door then you will switch away from it, so you will lose. If, however, you arbitrarily pick either of the two empty doors then when you switch it will be to the prize door, as the other empty door is guaranteed to have been removed. Thus you have a 2/3 chance of winning, as you have a 2/3 chance of initially picking an empty door.
 
 Obviously, if you decide pre-game not to switch then you will have an initial 1/3 chance of getting the prize door, and this will not change because the extra information provided by the host will not have affected your decision.
 
 Now, does it really matter at what point during the game you decide how to act? The important thing is the two-way interaction between you and the host, not when you decide whether to switch or not.
 
 
Suppose you were originally given TWO choices, and then you pick a door.
 The host comes along and says "Oh. By the way, we were originally going to give you THREE door options, and here is the third door. The prize is not behind door #3."
 Does that mean you should switch your choice now? 

 This scenario is different, in that the hosts interaction is irrelevant. The host is not giving you any new information here - you could just imagine him as having said that and nothing would have changed.
 
 The host's interaction in the original scenario is important, however, because it is guided by you. If you pick one of the empty doors then the host must remove the other empty door, regardless of what his original intentions were. This changes the odds from a 1/2 chance described by you here to the 1/3 and 2/3 chances calculated in the original situation.

The prize was never behind the now excluded door. That is new knowledge that you gain, which does change your chances but the re-calculated chances should not count now excluded door.
 

 
 The reason you need to include the excluded door is that you don't know which door is going to be excluded when you make your first choice. Thus, your first choice has a 2/3 of being wrong. And IF your first choice was wrong, then switching will always lead to victory, right? So if you always switch then 2/3 of the time you will start with the wrong door, but then switch to the right one and win.

... because when you switch you declare that you were more likely to be wrong with your first choice, so you are more likely to win by switching from that [more likely] wrong choice to the [more likely] correct one, which after interaction with the host is the only possible option.
